title: How to Stock Your Pantry for Mexican Cooking

steps.headline: Find Mexican Allspice.
steps.description: This popular spice is in almost every dish, and it is also known as pimienta gorda, or “fat peppercorn.” Allspice is typically ground up and mixed into dishes to add more flavor to salsas, stews, and sauces.

steps.headline: Add aromatic herbs.
steps.description: Mexican Oregano, Mexican bay leaves, thyme, and marjoram are bundled together to create aromatic herbs. These are used to cook many savory Mexican dishes and soups. You can use these herbs either fresh or dried. Mexican oregano and bay leaves are unique to Mexico, but you can substitute common oregano or bay leaves if need be.

steps.headline: Include achiote.
steps.description: Achiote, also known as annatto in English, is a spice used to add a ruby color and rich flavor to meat and rice. It has a subtle earthy flavor and goes great in marinades. Achiote comes in seed, paste, or block form. Blocks of achiote tend to be the easiest to use, but all forms offer similar effects.

steps.headline: Locate Mexican cinnamon.
steps.description: Mexican cinnamon is slightly lighter in color with a thinner, crumbly bark. It has a warmer, headier flavor than common cinnamon. Cinnamon is used in creating flavor bases of moles, desserts, and beverages like Horchata. Use common cinnamon if Mexican cinnamon is not available.

steps.headline: Get garlic.
steps.description: This delicious, strong flavor is often used in sauces, marinades, meat rubs, and soups.

steps.headline: Feature cilantro.
steps.description: Cilantro is the perfect garnish to nearly any Mexican dish, as cilantro can have a bitter flavor if cooked. Sprinkle a little cilantro on your dish right before serving, or add cilantro to your salsas.

steps.headline: Gather chili peppers.
steps.description: Mexican food heavily revolves around chilis for flavor, and many different chilis create many different tastes. The hot and spicy flavor of chili peppers are critical to preparing Mexican dishes. Common chili peppers in Mexican cuisine include: anaheim chilis, guajillo chilis, dried arbol chilis, ancho chilis, chipotles en adobo, poblanos chilis, jalapenos, and habaneros. Anaheim are more mild while habaneros are extremely spicy. You can substitute bell peppers to make the flavor more mild. Bell peppers can be served raw or cooked.

steps.headline: Gather tortillas.
steps.description: Tortillas are made out of either flour or corn. Tortillas make the meal in Mexican cooking, acting as either the dish itself, the plate, or the utensil. You can make tortillas from scratch or buy them in your local grocery store. If buying tortillas in a store, check the food label and select the tortilla with the fewest ingredients. Typically, the fewer the ingredients, the fresher the food.

steps.headline: Buy dried black and pinto beans.
steps.description: Beans are the most versatile ingredient in Mexican cooking. You can use your beans to fill your favorite dish, prepare as a side dish, or make into refried beans. There are also many recipes you can make with any leftover beans, like soup or sauces.

steps.headline: Pick up white rice.
steps.description: Rice can be used in a variety of Mexican dishes. You can prepare a variety of rice dishes by either using different cooking techniques or by adding seasoning or flavors. Make red rice or “Mexican rice” by cooking blanched rice in hot oil with tomatoes and broth. Make green rice by cooking with parsley and chiles. Make horchata, a popular drink, by mixing rice flour with sugar and cinnamon.

steps.headline: Experiment with pepitas.
steps.description: Pepitas, or pumpkin seeds, are widely used in Mexico. They are roasted and salted to eat as snacks, and they are ground up to use in sauces. Sometimes these seeds are used in traditional candies. You can also garnish your dish of choice with pepitas, like salads.

steps.headline: Get Mexican chocolate.
steps.description: Mexican chocolate is bitter in flavor and spiced with cinnamon. It is used to flavor certain beverages, desserts, and mole sauces. You can usually find this at a Mexican goods store.

steps.headline: Purchase lard.
steps.description: Lard is the preferred fat in Mexican cooking. Lard's rich flavor helps enhance the flavor of anything else it is cooked with. It is often used in making flour, tortillas, and tamales. Many tortilla-based snacks are fried in lard. You can buy lard at butcher counters or Mexican grocery stores. Store lard in refrigerator after opening.

steps.headline: Buy canned tomatoes.
steps.description: Stock up on canned tomatoes, as you will use these for nearly every sauce. Tomatoes are often used in salads, rice dishes, and stews. Fresh tomatoes will make your dishes taste a bit more authentic, but canned produce is a great way to have your ingredients ready use. Also look for tomatillos, or also known as green tomatoes. They have a more tart taste than tomatoes. Tomatillos are often cooked in pork or prepared in salsa verde.

steps.headline: Purchase canned corn.
steps.description: Corn will quickly become one of your staple ingredients. Corn is known as the “gift of the gods” in Mexico. Corn is in almost all Mexican dishes—tacos, soups, enchiladas, tamales, stews, tortillas, and even drinks.

steps.headline: Use canned beans.
steps.description: If dried beans are not available, you can substitute canned beans. Dried beans take a little longer to cook, so having a back-up can is helpful for quick meals. You will use beans very frequently in Mexican cooking.

steps.headline: Get canned peppers.
steps.description: If you do not have access to fresh chili peppers, you can purchase canned peppers instead. Jalapenos are commonly found in cans, as are many other chili peppers.
